title: Exercise and Longevity
content: Exercise helps us live longer. It is important as we age and can have a significant impact on health. Exercise impacts the autonomic nervous system, blood pressure, heart rate, heart rate variability, heart rate recovery, and max heart rate. It also influences VO2 max, which declines as we age. Exercise can also reduce the risk factors that contribute to cardiovascular disease and all-cause mortality, including blood pressure, diabetes, lipids and cholesterol, and stress management. Exercise also improves endothelial function and positively influences the autonomic nervous system.

title: Benefits of Exercise
content: Exercise extends life and reduces all-cause mortality. It improves a collection of lifestyle-related factors: the autonomic nervous system, blood pressure, lipids, the lining of the blood vessels, and diabetes. Natural experiments in exercise show a 50% reduction in cardiovascular and all-cause mortality. Exercise can add 3-5 years to life expectancy and 6-8 years of improved healthspan.

title: Exercise and Age-Related Decline
content: Exercise can mitigate age-related decline in strength and stability. Without deliberate training, people can start to decline at age 30. With training, this can be pushed back to age 40. As people get into their 40s and 50s, they need to think about adding strength training or some sort of circuit training and agility training to their program. Exercise preserves fitness in old age and can prevent falls and the inability to do things.

title: Age-Related Decline in Physical Activity, Muscle Mass, and Strength
content: There’s an amazing study that demonstrates muscle mass changes, strength changes, and activity changes in men and women as they age. At the age of 75, there are huge declines in physical activity, muscle mass, and strength. This begs the question, “Is the patient losing strength because they are no longer active, or are they no longer active because they have lost strength?” It's suspected that the loss of strength occurs first and contributes to the loss of activity.

title: Exercise Preserves Fitness in Old Age
content: Studies of some Swedish cross-country skiers, men who were world and Olympic champions in the 40s and 50s, remained very active and were studied in their 80s, and their fitness levels were similar to what you would see in people in very early middle age. Classic studies from the 60s of fighter pilots sent into outer space showed that they would go into outer space for a week and come back with terrible muscle atrophy. They couldn’t stand up.

title: Impact of Inactivity on Physiological Function
content: Incredibly, 3 weeks of bedrest caused losses of physiological function associated with 30 years of aging. This is why it’s so important to avoid inactivity of any type. Even low grade physical activity, such a walking a dog, gardening, taking a flight of stairs once in a while or intentionally working out is really the way to go.

title: Exercise, Mortality and Fracture Risk
content: The mortality of 65-year olds (and older) who suffer a fall that results in the fracture of any part of the hip or femur at 1 year can be as low as 25% or as high as 60%. Studies of people who lived a long life reveal the benefits of exercise. They were non-smokers, they weren’t obese, they remained physically active, they ate modestly, they stayed engaged in life.

title: Exercise and the Autonomic Nervous System
content: Your autonomic nervous system is what controls your internal environment. It maintains homeostasis. There are 2 branches of the autonomic nervous system - the sympathetic nerves and the parasympathetic nerves. The key thing to remember, is that the autonomic nervous system helps you regulate the internal environment and that exercise really keeps these things tuned-up.

title: Exercise and Metrics of Fitness
content: VO2 max testing measures blood pressure throughout. During exercise blood pressure is high, heart rate is high, heart rate variability (HRV) is low. What happens is the system shifts a little bit to meet the demands of the skeletal muscle. You’ve got to be able to contract the muscles to exercise. This is consistent with the fight or flight thing. And so to do that, you need to send more blood flow to those muscles, and one of the ways you do that is by increasing your blood pressure (more blood pressure equals more flow).

title: VO2 Max and Mortality
content: Reduction in all-cause mortality with increased fitness levels and VO2 max. VO2 max is measured by hooking a person up to EKG electrodes and have them ride a bike or run on a treadmill. They would use a nose clip/ face mask/ mouthpiece to measure how much they breathe in and out. An unfit person in their 30s or 40s can typically increase that about 8 or 10 fold to say, 30 or 35 or about 3 liters a minute. With training, most people can increase things at least 10-20%. Once your VO2 max goes up, it’s a measure of physical fitness; and it’s also linked to all-cause mortality. The fitter you are, the lower your chance of dying in the next year or 2 years, 5 years, 10 years.

title: METs and Exercise
content: The MET is a measure of the ratio of expended energy relative to a person’s mass. It allows comparison of different physical activities. For many years, they thought that benefit from exercise plateaued at what they call about 10 or 12 METs. Henry Ford in Detroit has shown that benefits from exercise continues to rise even up to 15, 16 METs. People that are quite fit continue to gain benefit in terms of all cause mortality.

title: Fitness and All-Cause Mortality
content: All-cause mortality was inversely proportional to cardiorespiratory fitness. There is a 5 fold increase in all-cause mortality between the fittest 2.5% and the least fit 25%. Even when you look at something less extreme, compare the least fit 25% to the 3rd quartile (Low vs Above average), the hazard ratio is 2.75. This is right on par with the increase in mortality you would see from having end stage renal disease. This is greater than the hazard ratio associated with smoking.

title: Exercise and Cardiovascular Disease
content: The benefits of exercise in reducing cardiovascular disease. For people who pick up exercise late in life, remember that exercise is not a vaccine. While you could still have some blockages even if you exercise, and there are people with horrible lipids who do in fact get heart disease in spite of exercise, exercise is not a complete vaccine, but the overall protective effect is quite large, both in terms of what it does to people’s lipids, and the fact that the blood vessels get so much bigger, and the linings of the blood vessels are healthier.

title: Exercise and Longevity
content: The literature argues there is a J curve. The person who doesn’t exercise has the highest risk of mortality. As a person begins to exercise their risk of mortality goes down. But at a certain point, more MET hours (50-75 MET hours per week depending on the study) is associated with a higher mortality risk. The one thing that does happen is people have an apparent increase in risk of atrial fibrillation. One caveats is they do not have any increased risk of fatal arrhythmias.

title: Mitigating Age-Related Decline in Fitness
content: Data from Ben Levine’s group down in Dallas show that fit young people have very flexible, compliant heart muscles. They show that declines with age. But it doesn’t decline nearly so fast in people that are either habitual exercisers or people who remain master athletes/ highly competitive. His data show that training keeps the ventricles compliant, flexible and able to handle the increased demands and pumping demands of exercise.

title: VO2 Max and Age
content: The reason you want to have a high VO2 max when you’re young is to prepare for the inevitability of decline. VO2 max declines about 10% per decade, starting in the 4th decade. A lot of that is driven by age-related decline in heart rate. But in people that are not training, it’s because their heart can’t pump as much blood and their muscles can’t use it. Among people who are training, they start at a higher level. If people continue to train, they probably don’t see a big decline until their late 30s or early 40s. You can reduce the rate of decline by about half, certainly up to your 70s probably. If people stop training, their VO2 max falls precipitously.

title: VO2 Max and Daily Activities
content: A VO2 max of 14 mL/kg or 4 METs is required from an oxygen consumption perspective for people to do their activities of daily living. This means an occasional somewhat brisk walk for a few minutes, to be able to get around the house, to go to the supermarket and be independent. If you want to be able to run a mile in 10 minutes, that would be 35 VO2 max or 10 METs. If someone in their 80s had a VO2 max in the 20s-lower 30s, that would be terrific.

title: VO2 Max and Physical Fitness
content: How many pushups do you want to be able to do? How many sorts of body weight type of things do you want to be able to do? What sort of agility maneuvers do you want to be able to do? We have to factor in orthopedic problems and that sort of thing, but again, we have good treatment for those now and our orthopedic surgeons can fix a lot of things that otherwise would’ve made it difficult for people to walk and move around.

title: Variables that Drive VO2 Max
content: What drives VO2 max? Broadly speaking, there are 3 variables: 1 – The gas exchange in the lungs, 2 – The pump efficiency, 3 – The gas exchange in the muscle bed. These are the big 3 of 4-5 steps. You’ve got (1) air to lung, (2) lung to blood, (3) blood from the heart to the tissues, and (4) oxygen from the blood to the tissues. In general, oxygen uptake is cardiac output (how much blood you’re pumping per minute) times arteriovenous oxygen difference (how much oxygen you’re extracting out of the blood).

title: Peak Heart Rate and VO2 Max
content: As individuals age, we think the majority of the reduction in VO2 max comes from a reduction in cardiac output. The majority is probably coming from a reduction in peak heart rate. This can be buffered to some extent if you have a nice compliant ventricle.

title: Training Regimens and Aerobic Efficiency
content: When you look at the best high output endurance athletes today, it’s one thing to talk about their peak engine performance, but it’s easy to overlook what they’re doing at the low end. That low end aerobic efficiency is impressive. If your VO2 max represents the height or peak of your pyramid, the wider your base, the higher your peak.

title: Running and Lactate Levels
content: Running at a pace of 4:40 miles doesn't cause much of an increase in blood lactate acid levels. At the end of a marathon, carbohydrate levels would be low. The highest performance level is likely around 90% of max. It's difficult for people to run more than about 120 or 130 miles a week due to the impact and potential for orthopedic issues.

title: Training Regimen of Elite Long Distance Runners
content: Elite long distance runners typically train 2-4 hours a day. Their training includes a lot of medium 8 and 10 and 12 miles runs, a couple of hard interval sessions per week, and a long run. This gets them to 120 miles a week, week in and week out. They also do strength training and bodyweight training.

title: Improvements in Sports Medicine
content: The metrics of elite athletes haven’t improved so much as sports medicine has gotten better. Sports medicine is better, so if people get injured, they can recover. They don’t stop when they’re 25-26. Most of the improved performance can be attributed to equipment and these sort of social factors.

title: Health Benefits of Light Exercise
content: There is a health benefit to low-intensity (zone 2) exercise. The health benefits of just less than brisk walking are substantial. It’s purposeful, but not really brisk walking. The health benefits of light physical activity, light exercise, are substantial and there is no J curve. 10-15 minutes of light physical activity begins to do things in your skeletal muscle. Then it improves your insulin sensitivity and helps you fight against diabetes.

title: Training Metrics and Regimen
content: Simple metrics to track include how much time you are training, how much time you are spending where you’re really short of breath, a little bit short of breath, and at a pleasant sort of pace. The main thing is to make sure that you have some accountability. It can be a training partner, maybe with a device or a diary, maybe with just how far did I run today.

title: VO2 Max and Weight
content: The VO2 max was 5.4 L/min when the individual was younger and weighed between 75-80 kg. Now, the individual weighs about 95 kg and estimates the VO2 max to be around 4.5 L/min.

title: Rate of Perceived Exertion (RPE)
content: On easy recovery days, the focus is on RPE (rate of perceived exertion), which is essentially active rest.

title: Heart Rate Monitoring
content: The individual does not measure heart rate. The peak heart rate is estimated to be about 140. The individual tracks RPE and has the ability to do intervals on their own.

title: Boosting VO2 Max with Interval Training
content: One of the most efficient ways to improve VO2 max is to use a 4 x 4 protocol. This involves 4 minutes on, 4 minutes off. For example, cycling on an incline for 4 minutes, followed by 4 minutes of recovery. This is repeated four times. The power should be kept as steady as possible.

title: Advice for Average Person
content: For the average person, the hard part of interval training is maintaining consistent effort for 4 minutes, with the suffering disproportionately occurring in the last 90 seconds. When you finish the last one, you should not be bending over. If you had gone a little faster, you’d want to be bending over.

title: Exploring Limits with Interval Training
content: Interval training can lead to a sort of religious experience exercising. It involves managing your suffering and maintaining your rhythm and tempo.

title: Form and Tempo of Elite Athletes
content: Elite athletes maintain their form and tempo even under great effort. This is seen in sports like swimming, running, golf, and basketball.

title: Training Advice for the Average Person
content: For a recreational person who’s never trained in their life, everything is based off RPE (rate of perceived exertion). They should work at a level where they can talk but not enjoy it, no higher. This might start out as 2-3 hours per week. After about 6 months of this kind of training, they can move to the next phase which includes a 4 x 4, for 4 rounds (4 on + 4 off), once a week.

title: Boosting VO2 Max with Hard Intervals
content: Doing 4 hard intervals once a week is sufficient to boost VO2 max for the vast majority of people. After being able to do 4 rounds of 4 x 4, once a week, they can build up to 2x per week.

title: Professional Athletes' Longer Careers
content: Exceptional elite athletes can have longer careers due to better sports medicine and professionalization of sports. This allows them to make enough money to make it worth their while to continue.

title: Endurance Sports and Health
content: Cycling and swimming are the endurance sports. These tests are typically designed so there’s not a lot of false positives. So that gives people some room to microdose. But occasionally people will be caught through investigations, judicial mechanisms, the police. Historically, many of the biggest busts have been made by the police.

title: Doping in Sports
content: Mike contends that the era of industrial strength doping is over. People are no longer doing like the East Germans did and androgenizing females to the extent that they really look like men. What the Russians did less than a decade ago was relatively low dose by comparison. There are probably a bunch of novel compounds out there. Small peptides that cause this to be released or that to be released, which would be very difficult to detect. They’d have vanishing short half-lives. And they would just boost your endogenous production of hormone X, Y, or Z, something like a growth hormone-releasing factor, something that caused testosterone levels to go up or suffer.

title: Performance Enhancement Agents
content: Is human growth hormone still one of the more utilized agents today for performance enhancement? Human growth hormone (HGH) is not something that can be readily tested for. Mike’s guess is that there’s probably some of it going on. He thinks people have probably drifted back to more low-dose/short-acting androgens and hope for the best. The same would be true with low dose EPO and/or related compounds.

title: Exercise and Health
content: Can some of the benefits of exercise be captured by a pharmaceutical strategy? Success in research has primarily focused on things that increase mitochondrial biosynthesis. This appears to work in animal models. Exercise makes your mitochondria better or makes more of them. But [a pill] making your mitochondria better isn’t going to make your autonomic nervous system better, isn’t going to make your blood pressure better, isn’t going to necessarily make the lining of your blood vessels better, isn’t going to make your heart bigger, and so on and so forth.

title: Convalescent Plasma and COVID-19
content: When the pandemic struck in March/April of 2020, Mike became the principal investigator of the US Convalescent Plasma Program. This program that was initially designed to facilitate the compassionate use of convalescent plasma in 5,000 patients. Antibody-rich plasma from recovered COVID patients would be given to people who had disease, and hopefully, the antibodies would help them. The program ended up treating over 100,000 people. They found evidence when they gave people a whole lot of antibody early in the course of disease, it made them better. They also found some evidence that it was probably very helpful in people that were immunosuppressed.

title: COVID Plasma Donors
content: Within 2-3 weeks up until 3-4 months after a person is infected and recovers from COVID, they are a suitable plasma donor. This period may extend up to 6 months, especially if they got boosted. Initially, before vaccines were available, only people who recovered from infection were used. Now that vaccines have been widely available for 18 months, people who’ve had both vaccination and recovery from infection are also used. These people are considered super donors and can donate multiple units of plasma.

title: Convalescent Serum Availability
content: Work is being done with the FDA and various health societies to ensure convalescent serum is available for patients with conditions like lymphoma or leukemia. In France, about 50 patients a week are treated with convalescent sera. If this was scaled up in the US to match the larger population, it would be about 300 patients a week.

title: Plasma Donation Logistics
content: There are many people who have recovered from infection, and who have been vaccinated and infected, making them potential donors. However, there are logistical issues around getting these people to the blood collection center. The blood should be typed in cross, and donors have to be eligible to otherwise donate blood. During the peak of plasma use, around 20,000 to 40,000 units a week were being used in the country. There was a correlation between the use of convalescent plasma and a lower death rate 2 weeks later.

title: Current State of Fitness and Exercise
content: There is a need for society to address the issue of physical activity. While upper middle class kids have access to superb coaching and facilities, there is a problem with play and unstructured play for many others. Opportunities for unstructured play time in parks and at school have fallen by the wayside. The lack of open gyms, especially during summer, is a problem. The idea of a national open gym movement is suggested as a solution.

title: Workplace Physical Activity
content: Encouraging physical activity in the workplace can be beneficial. For example, secretaries at the Mayo Clinic would bring their tennis shoes and walk around the hospital's large bunker system during their lunch break. This not only provided them with physical activity but also served as a social event and increased their productivity.
